Award.AwardTitle: Protein dynamics and the evolution of enzyme catalysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division funds this research. Professors Amnon Kohen and Christopher Cheatum at the University of Iowa investigate how enzymes accelerate chemical reactions. Enzymes are protein molecules. They are large and dynamic, and vibrate very fast. The research seeks to find out if specific vibrations of the protein contribute to the extraordinary rate accelerations of the enzyme-catalyzed reactions. The investigators devise new molecular tools that make it possible to measure fast vibrations in specific places in the enzyme. Comparing the changes in the reactants with the changes in the motions of the protein reveal the role that protein's motions play in the reactivity. This research gives graduate and undergraduate students specialized training in a diverse and unique scientific skill set. The outreach activities have a demonstrated record of engaging high school students in basic science and steering some toward studies and careers in science. These activities enhance scientific awareness for other students who are not interested in scientific careers.

This research project identifies correlations between enzyme dynamics and chemical reactivity of carbon-hydrogen carbon (C-H C) transfer reactions. The role of networks of coupled motions of the protein in modulating that relationship in dihydrofolate reductase is also examined. The effects of both active-site and distal mutations on the chemical step by the temperature dependence of the primary kinetic isotope effects (KIEs) and on the protein dynamics by two-dimensional infrared (2D IR) spectroscopy are measured. Mutants that have previously been studied using KIEs that suggest a role for enzyme motions in the catalyzed reaction are used for the combined spectroscopic and kinetic studies. Differences between the human and E. coli enzymes are assessed and compared to theoretical predictions for these two related enzymes. This research gives graduate and undergraduate students specialized training in a diverse and unique scientific skill set. The combination of methods may be quite general and apply to a range of enzymes. This project is integrated with an outreach effort to communicate this science to the public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The motions of enzymes are essential for their function. Motions at the fastest possible time scale play important roles in controlling the chemical reactions that enzymes facilitate, but these motions are not well understood nor are the ways that the protein structure dictates motions that ultimately control the chemistry. In this research, we have made changes to a protein and measured the effects of those changes on both the protein motions and the chemical reaction occuring in the protein. We have demonstrated a correlation between those measurements.

In addition, we have also studied how the evolutionary changes in different parts of a protein work together to preserve the motions that control the chemistry. We have studied networks of residues in the protein and shown that they perturbations of residues that belong to such a network in a human enzyme exhibit the same effects as the corresponding mutations in the bacterial enzyme. In addition, we have shown evolutionary changes in sequence that occur simultaneously must happen simultamneously to preserve the motions that are important in controlling the chemical reaction. In the human protein changing one co-evolving part to be like the bacterial enzyme but not the other parts degrades the chemical properties of the enzyme. In contrast, changing both parts of the protein that are known to evolve together to be lke the bacterial enzyme restores function that is similar to the fully evolved bacterial enzyme. Together these results show that evolution preserves the motions that are involved in the chemical reaction and not just the overall structure.

In addition to these new scientific insights, our work has also developed the methods used in this research making the experimental approaches that we use applicable to a wide range of new systems. Together with the scientific results, these outcomes have the potential to impact protein engineering, drug discovery, and a wide range of other fields in chemistry and biology.

Along with these intellectual merits, this project has had a range of broader impacts. First, it has advanced the careers of several young scientists. The students who work on these collaborative and multidisciplinary projects gain valuable research experiences. Five graduate students and two undergraduates have participated in this project. Of those students three are women and two are first generation college students. Three of the graduate students completed their Ph.D. degrees, and both of the undergraduates have moved on to graduate and medical schools. The Ph.D. students have pursued careers both in academia and in industry.

Beyond my research program, I have also engaged in significant outreach efforts. I have been on the Advisory Board for the Latham Science Engagement Initiative and Fellowship Program, which engages students in communicating how science impacts our everyday lives and can address major social challenges. Students work in teams to design and implement outreach projects, which have covered a range of topics including teaching physics with animations, epidemic simulations, the art of science, and communicating science through blogging. Through the program, 62 students have impacted 2759 people who have participated in events, and their work has resulted in print publications, digital sites, and podcasts, which have a significant broader impact. For the past two years I have also participated with Skype A Scientist. This program connects scientists with classrooms for a 30-60 minute online Q&A session in which the scientist talks about their work, what they do every day, and how they became a scientist. This program gives students a chance to meet a ?real? scientist, even if they live in a place where they lack access to scientific research facilities. These outreach activites are an important prt of the broader impact of this NSF funded project.
